content: more love for the puny space elves this week we're gonna build something that is
inspired by and a similar to but definitely not the same as an elder
Wraith Lord
a couple weeks ago I made this guide and posted it you can pause and read it if
you want but this is how I come up with all the specific dimensions that I'm
about to give you I want my scratch builds to be the same
size as their real world model in the interest of fidelity we'll start by
making the legs cut a length of drinking straw 60 millimeters long with the bendy
part in the middle of it for the hip connection we're going to use a gear
like bead so chop off some of the straw to account for the width of that bead so
that the leg is still 60 millimeters now inject the straw with hot glue on both
ends don't need to fill it completely just get a bunch in there for the foot
take some thin cardstock and measure out a rectangle six millimeters wide and 18
millimeters long and then to narrow triangles along the two long ends like
you see here cut it out and fold the triangles then hot glue the longer end
of the straw into the foot making sure to position it at a slight angle
depending on how far forward you want the figure to lean then chop a couple
thin cardboard strips about a quarter inch wide and hot glue them so they wrap
over the foot like this now inject more hot glue into a straw and then chop a
piece that is 13 millimeters long hot glue the legs together with it
and then chop a five millimeter long
piece and hot glue it to the center pointing upwards for the main torso from
extruded polystyrene otherwise known as home insulation available at your local
home improvement store cut a block that is 18 millimeters wide across the chest
15 millimeters tall from neck down and 15 millimeters deep from front of chest
to back and then on the front which would be the chest taper it twice like
this
at this point I hot-glued the feet to my sixty millimeter base which I made using
my 3d printer although chipboard or other very heavy
cardstock will do just fine and then hot glue the torso to the leg assembly now
from dollar-store foam board cut a piece that is thirty millimeters wide and
sixteen millimeters tall and then from that rectangle chop away some pieces
until it looks something like this and hot glue it to the back of the torso for
these wing like things on the back I just used chipboard and I measured a
rectangle forty millimeters tall and seventeen millimeters wide and within
that rectangle I just freehand drew based on the picture make to cut them
out and hot glue to the back of the torso on to the head here's an earring
this is just some cheap costume jewelry I'm going to break off the pin from the
back and then hot glue this to a strip of chipboard and then cut a triangle out
of some foam and hot glue that on as well this is intended to approximate the
shape of the head else make the sword here's some very
small beads which fit tightly onto a toothpick so I cut a toothpick 20
millimeters long and slide the beads onto both ends and then on some
chipboard again I just freehand drew the blade 50 millimeters long
cut it out in hot glue it to the hilt arms the arms are 35 millimeters long
cut a drinking straw to 35 millimeters but unlike the legs don't Center the
bendy part instead there should be 10 millimeters on one side of the bendy and
then just measure off 35 from that mark this short 10 millimeter side is the
upper arm and the longer side is the lower arm which will ultimately connect
to the hand so hot glue another connecting bead to the upper arm and
then hot glue that to the torso remember to bend the right arm and keep the left
one mostly straight as for the hand holding the sword chop a 5 millimeter
long piece of drinking straw cut it open lengthwise add some hot glue in there
and then insert the sword then hot glue the entire thing to the arm
now I'm not gonna be labor the next
phase I used thin 60 pound cardstock the stuff that I always use for corrugation
cladding and cut small pieces to wrap around various parts of the model
simulating armor plating refer to the source image and just let your
imagination guide you I recommend cutting squares that are a three-quarter
inch and from there round the corners or bevel um or do whatever you want to but
I found that three-quarters of an inch was good for wrapping partially around
the drinking straw and now the good part the bright lanes the overall length of
the bright lance is 60 millimeters so I injected a straw with hot glue cut a
taper on one end and then shoved in this kind of elongated bead known how the hot
glue makes the straw conform to the shape of the bead because it's so hot
and that's nice for hiding the scene then t-shape from foam board hot glue
that to the bead and lastly a smaller oval shaped bead
mounted on top for this site hot glue the whole thing to the back torso piece
on the figures left
and moving on to painting again I'm not going to be labor this we've done this a
lot on the channel I'm gonna base in white because I'm gonna be using red and
a white base coat makes it much easier to get a solid coverage of red so then
base in red hit the joints with black and the head with white probably I'll
need multiple coats and as I've done dozens of times before flock the base
with pebbles and sand and then paint see episode 57 for this particular ground
scheme and lastly the banner between the legs
I made this in Photoshop as described in episode 9 just going to attach it to the
crossbar between the legs using a tiny amount of Loctite gel control super glue
and here it is in context next to the dread-nots we did in episode 54 and you
can see it also did some random white accents all over the place again just
drawing inspiration from the source image not exact recreation just
inspiration I also super glued a small green Swarovski crystal to the site on
the bright Lance I am wile Ock thank you for joining me
and I'll see you next time
